# News comment title:
New Ads Push the Supreme Court to Broadcast Oral Arguments

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Very disappointed in Sotomayor.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
I think the process could be more misleading than helpful,”Sotomayor said.

.............
The public has the right to listen to pure oral arguments before having GOP and media slice and dice the oral arguments into pieces, which would create misleading.  I think Judge's Sotomayor is wrong on this issue.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


As much as I'd like to hear them, I think the last thing a Supreme Court justice needs in the back of their mind when forming questions is: "how is fox/msnbc going to spin this quote tonight?"

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
The brazen labor abuse throughout America seems to know no bounds.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
The brazen labor abuse throughout America seems to know no bounds.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


The problem I have with your comment is the implicit sexism it contains, especially in the context of this article.  I'm far from a radical feminist, but even I was insulted by that.

Furthermore, your pilot article is totally meaningless.  If these claims are even half true, your average waitress makes more than most of these women are making.  Before tips.  A pilot's salary would be 700% increase.

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
He's so entirely lunatic that probably the inbreds of his district will just stay home and pick the fleas off their dogs instead of vote.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
He's so entirely lunatic that probably the inbreds of his district will just stay home and pick the fleas off their dogs instead of vote.

# News comment title:
Can You Guess When Violent Crime in Our Schools Peaked?

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Leaded Gasoline. Hello, old friend.

I'd like to add that Nirvana also peaked in 1993 when they released In Utero. There must be correlation there somewhere.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Oddly enough, of acute terminal lead poisoning.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Do you actually think this is a well-written, well-supported article?  Do you think that graph is good science in any way?

I'm being critical, so you're entitled to be a stickler.  I should have wrote "all the INCREASE IN violence".  I suspect you knew exactly what I meant, but okay, you got me.  How does that changes the issues with this article?

Kevin's previous posts are not even referenced in the article.  That doesn't get a pass when one sentence (hell, one clause:  As I've discussed earlier, "link") would solve the problem.

And nothing excuses that graph.

I'm not coming here to troll.  I'm pretty liberal on most issues.  However, if we are going to try and claim science to support our beliefs, we need to hold that science to some decent standards.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
Obama Goes off on Mass Shootings

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
I don't understand why such intelligent people are feeding into this theory that more gun control is going to get guns out of the hands of people who shouldn't have them. In my town, there are unregistered guns, bought illegally, hidden all over the place. As long as you know where they are, you can just go to the drop spot, use the gun, and then rehide it and let everyone know where it is. But sure...gun control's gonna stop that.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Because Australia.

You are making the point, actually.  In your town, there are guns everywhere.  That's exactly the problem.  If there were fewer of them, there'd be less problem.

Offer buybacks for the guns that are out there.  Nobody's confiscating your guns, but if you'd like to make some cash discarding some of the extras you've got, it's your choice.

Restrict new gun purchases to defensive and sporting weapons only.  You don't need weapons of war (offensive weapons) unless you want to join the "well-regulated militia".  We already don't generally let civilians buy M-60 machine guns, all we're doing is moving that dividing line further down the scale.  Even Justice Scalia said the 2nd Amendment isn't absolute.

Lifetime ownership.  You buy a gun, its serial number and ballistic prints are registered to you for life.  Your only transfer options are the buyback program or passing it down to family who then get the lifetime ownership.  If your gun is used to harm another, you get 50% of whatever punishment the shooter gets.  Theft of your gun is no defense - gee, didn't you have a gun to deter theives?  (Wanna bet folks will be extra careful to lock up their guns?)


Bullet control.  The 2nd Amendment protects the right to bear arms.  It doesn't say a thing about ammo.  Regulate the hell out of ammo purchases.  Background check for every purchase.  Quantity limits.  You name it.

When I hear "guns don't kill people, people kill people" I think I agree, and it seems that the people in the United States like to kill people quite often with guns.  When I hear "it's mental health, it's culture" I think I agree, and it seems we have a crazy killing culture.  If we're such a crazy killing nation, perhaps we should have fewer guns to crazily kill each other with.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Do you actually think that there's any room to compromise with the NRA, a group that literally said the answer to school massacres is arming more people?

The solution to guns in schools is more guns in schools?  How do you compromise with that?

>>> END COMMENT <<<

Thanks for responding.  Hopefully this can be productive and civil.

What human system IS foolproof?  If I had no choice but an alarm that worked some of the time and nothing, I'd take the alarm.

Yes, the media reports mass shootings to garner ratings-- no one is arguing that.  But you can't honestly be saying they're not increasing, both in number and severity.

How do we do anything about mental illness without a comprehensive background check system, which the NRA also fights tooth and nail?

As far as mental health goes, sure, it needs a revamp as well.  However, I'll think you'll find that the VA was quite well liked by veterans until the Iraq War, when it was severely overtaxed and underfunded.

If we're such a crazy killing nation, perhaps we should have fewer guns to crazily kill each other with.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


I doubt that the entirety (or even the majority) of illegal guns in this country are imported, simply because of Occam's Razor:  it's far easier to get the guns from the country their made in.  Is there anything to disprove that?  I'm totally willing to be proven wrong.

If I'm not wrong, then there have to be legal buyers turning the guns over to illegal hands.  Or is the pool of illegal arms so large that criminals can continue to draw from it with no need of replenishment?

Again, if I'm not wrong, how do we combat legal buying as a front for illegal activities?  Tag the guns to a purchase?  Install personal IDs on the guns (the NRA was vehemently against "SmartGuns", correct?  Granted, the sunset clause in the NJ law was idiotic and so obviously inciteful it seems designed to fail).

I also agree that the penal system needs vast overhaul.  Drug enforcement in this country is absolutely insane, and does nothing to help its own cause-- and much to help private prison companies.  Prison should be a place for violent, socially maladjusted people that are a danger to others.  Reorienting the view on drugs so that drug offenses were no longer the majority of the prison population would go a long way to helping clean up gun violence in the cities.

But what do we do about mass shootings?  What is the gun-enthusiast answer to that?

Finally, I will certainly grant you that the firearm owners in this country get a bad rap.  However, you'll have to grant me that the Revolutionary rhetoric and the extremism common to them does not help your cause much.  No one is being oppressed by a tyrant king (and, really, even the American Revolutionaries didn't have it that bad, comparatively speaking.  Their complaints mainly stemmed from taxes and representation, not being killed and oppressed), so trying to equate modern day to that is a bit counterproductive, and more than a little scary to non-gun owners.

Full credit to the NRA for denouncing the idiots bringing long guns into Applebees and Chipotle.  I wish they played that message as loudly as they do to defend guns when a school gets shot up, but I'll take what I can get.

# News comment title:
Rand Paul Thinks Ebola Is More Contagious Than AIDS

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
I think this is one of those situations where public health professionals have a different definition of "contagious" than the rest of us. Paul's correct in pointing out that you can in theory be exposed to Ebola as a result of shaking hands with someone at a party--it's very unlikely, but it's possible. That's very different from the great lengths you have to go to to get HIV from someone. But I agree that there's unfounded panic in the U.S. over Ebola, and in reality it's not going to spread in the U.S. like it has been spreading in Africa, because we have a strong public health system.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
I think this is one of those situations where public health professionals have a different definition of "contagious" than the rest of us. Paul's correct in pointing out that you can in theory be exposed to Ebola as a result of shaking hands with someone at a party--it's very unlikely, but it's possible. That's very different from the great lengths you have to go to to get HIV from someone. But I agree that there's unfounded panic in the U.S. over Ebola, and in reality it's not going to spread in the U.S. like it has been spreading in Africa, because we have a strong public health system.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


MJ is deliberately misrepresenting and/or misunderstanding Paul here. You can, in fact, catch Ebola at a dinner party shaking hands- in theory. You cannot catch HIV through anything but direct fluid swap (blood or reproductive fluid). 

The NPR article deals with disease spread in a population, not singular transmission.

Some people have to work holidays. It would be better to make it a week, 6am to 10pm.

I'd gladly trade Columbus Day for Election Day.The Columbus Day mattress sales just don't seem as important as voting. 

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


I recently got dissuaded from this line of thinking. 

Firstly, the people that don't vote now aren't going to do so because they get the day off. Between voting by mail, early voting, etc, opportunity isn't the problem.  People who want to vote can, and do.

# News comment title:
What If Your Boss Suddenly Told You to Come to Work on Thanksgiving?

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
businesses are here to make money, employees are working to make money. But employees must realize that sometimes it is necessary to put in extra time to help the employer make his money.

Nothing is perfect unless you work (?) for the government, in which case you can not be fired unless you are a total nincompoop.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
I used to work at a big box store in the 70's. I had to print my own signs, make sure I didn't go over budget on salaries and other expenses, and learn to run the front end of the store and do all of the things to learn to eventually be a store manager. I also had to figure out the work schedule for all of my employees in my dept. and then as I got more departments, do the same for them.


First, I asked if any of them had any preferences. I had them pick a schedule that worked for them. At the end if there were any times when nobody wanted, we alternated to cover that, which still left them with a basically a fixed schedule. It took less time when I gave them a blank calendar and let them fill it in themselves. As long as my dept. was covered every hour the store was open and I didn't have to pay over time, I was fine. My dept. had the lowest turnover in employees, which cut down on training, and was always manned. If there was a reason that extra hours needed to be filled, I had plenty of volunteers. And I had almost nobody who called in sick.


All I needed was the dept. covered and to not go over budget. I never did.


I had one woman who was married with young kids, she picked a schedule that helped her with child care, saving her money. One kid who was in college, and some who wanted to work all days or all evenings. So for the most part, I was lucky. I repeated the same schedule for months at a time. It was perfect for me, happy employees, less time working out schedules, less people calling in sick, and not over budget. The store was open 9 A M -10 P M. A store can't be open more than 24 hours. Really easy my way.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


The headline deals with holidays, but the real crux is a lack of predictability of schedule. Not enough lead time to get child care in place, no routine to plan life around. 

Also, voluntary sign up would probably require holiday premium pay, something few retailers do. 

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
The War on Reproductive Rights Will Get a Lot Uglier Next Year

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Fetuses cannot feel pain, that is a lie.

They are incapable of consciousness prior to 25 weeks, and also sedated and anaesthetized in utero.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
I wish I knew. Pro lifers also consider fetuses to be parasites on society if their tax dollars are used to assist women with pre natal care, which would lower infant mortality.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Which discussion would you like to have?  A woman's choice to have sex or a woman's choice to continue pregnancy?

The actual pregnancies are identical, but the woman's consent to sex does matter greatly.  In one case, she knowingly accepted the possibility as a consequence of her actions, and in the other was deprived of that choice.  

I'm not even arguing for the outlawing of abortion-- I think it should continue to be legal and available, but it should also be discouraged from being treated as a form of birth control.  

Both men and women should understand that having sex may lead to a pregnancy, and terminating an inconvenient person (who had no say in the matter) shouldn't be some patch over poor decision making.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

It doesn't mean they do nothing through the trial, simply that they do not attempt to prove any evidence of their own, only to cast doubt on the prosecutions story.  This is done on cross-examinations and opening and closing statements. 

The defense is allowed to rest as its only action after the prosecution presents its entire case, and it's a common legal tactic because it implies that the defense believes the prosecution's case is so thin as to not be worthy of addressing further.

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
In the past when sugar was listed as a bad health guy, the corporate food industry got that trashed.  Now we have salt and cholesterol on the list for an adjusted mindset.  More in the diet and the body will bring out big pharma with their rotten statin drugs waving their swords.  So these super baby steps in the direction of health sanity are in precarious position relative to the big corporate interests which have been controlling health for too many decades now.

Solid fats need more readjustment.  This is a new term that fudges reality.  Hydrogenated fats are the issue; not fats.  Saturated fats are a necessary food in our diet for brain health as well as other health factors.  The industry, and science, with all due stupidity and laziness declared saturated fats the same as hydrogenated fats decades ago.  Despite all research to the contrary the USDA and other federal agencies has refused to update their mindset.  What is harmful are most seed oils such as corn oil which is used along with soy oil and canola oil in all commercial foods and often in home cooking.  These should be banned for their harmfulness.  

Coconut oil, a saturated fat, is one of the most healthful fats in the world.  But this country has made it sound like death incarnate.  Of course the US does not grow coconuts but went to monoculture products of corn and soy.  Now they are almost 100% GMO as well.  

Wouldn't it be nice if health decisions were made outside of politics and corporate interests and really focused on building health and prevention of disease.

Take it down a peg.  He actually has a point, in that there is some difficulty in a supposedly free society regulating what people can do to themselves.

Its a difficult philosophical question, and while I think the Libertarian answer of "do whatever you want and let God sort it out" is reductive and silly, its no better to say that his point has no validity.

The problem with universal health care (which I'm for, btw) is that it can't help but tie a personal choice to the preferences of the majority, and that limits freedom.  It's always going to be a balancing act, and what the price of being a member of society is.

# News comment title:
Let John Oliver Explain How Petty Municipal Fines Destroy the Lives of Our Most Vulnerable

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Don't they know the policeman is their friend?

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
It is the counties who are the robbers here.  Fines for minor violations go into the hundreds of dollars, yet paying them is like descending into the bowels of hell with all the lost souls and losing so much time that the experience can be as bad as the poverty it causes. 


Let's say you make minimum wage and work part-time.  Your old car does not pass the $100 smog test required for yearly registration--that money alone was nearly a week's pay to afford.  Repairing it would cost $850--a small fortune.  So you drive until the registration lapses, and a month later a cop pulls you over.  The nightmare begins.  


Your car is impounded, and the fees to get it out are more than the car is worth.  Now you have a car sitting in an impound lot that still needs $850 to fix but will require $400 just to get back.  And it still needs to be registered, which will cost $190.  But rather than help you find a way out, the court of law comes down on you with more punishment.  You have to get all of this done within 60 days or you face a fine that will equal to your entire monthly income, and if you miss this deadline, it will soon be as large as six months' pay.  


You go to the county court building to try to speak to someone and find hundreds of other poor people, most of them with brown or black skin, who are sick and disabled and treated worse than cattle, shuttled into lines that snake around the room and into a dark corridor.  When you finally wait in line for an hour only to be directed to another waiting area and finally are called up to talk to an employee, nothing can be done to change any of this. 


Your County has now taken your car and left you with a mountain of fines, fees and impossible hurdles to jump---and you have no way to drive anywhere now to do any of this.  Getting to work becomes a monumental problem.  There is NO WAY to speak to anyone about any of this--your county court does not answer its phone, not even if you remain on the line for half an hour.  You will finally hear the recording that says nobody will talk to you and realize that it's all hopeless.  


This is America, the land where the heavy hand of the law crushes citizens for minor infractions and takes everything they have, including their dignity.  It is criminal behavior that destroys people's lives.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Higher taxes. Municipal services are badly undefunded, creating an incentive for programs like this in order to make up the difference. 

>>> END COMMENT <<<

Once Again, We Are Unlearning the Lesson of the Great Debt Bubble

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
It'll start rolling once secondary companies get into it, buying up the loans and packaging them into asset-backed securities to be sold off private label style (just like before 2007). With so much money sloshing around and perpetually low interest rates, there's an endless appetite for anything with improved returns at the same rate of risk.

And what else should we have expected? Most of the companies involved didn't perish, nor the people working for them. Maybe it would have been different if all five of the investment banking giants had gone down in 2008, along with AIG and several banks - but even then I don't know. It's always going to be tempting. 

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
There is a fairly simple solution to the too-easy credit standard problem: require the credit issuer to hold the debt in their own account.  That is, not allow them to sell, securitize, or otherwise transfer the risk to another party.  Nothing like having your own money at risk to induce a sense of responsibility.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Someone here recently posted this LBJ quote:

You do not examine legislation in the light of the benefits it will convey if properly administered, but in the light of the wrongs it would do and the harms it would cause if improperly administered.

Seems appropriate here. 

>>> END COMMENT <<<

If the United States wasn't handcuffed by the demography of the Senate the Democratic Party would be in a much better position to do something about gun violence. As it stands, though, we absolutely need those sparsely-populated states in the Midwest and Rockies to provide us enough Senators to do something about more existentially threatening issues like war, climate change, and the economy.


If you ask me, letting the rural states jack off with their exploding dildos at the cost of a few ten thousand people dead to suicide/homicide is a fucking bargain compared to the collateral damage of their flipping out after getting their toys taken away.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
We can have sane conversations about, say, motorcycles. We can talk about appropriate design standards and extra licensing and age restrictions and even banning certain people from riding motorcycles in the way that we can't about guns. No one accuses people of talking about appropriate additives for gasolines as trying to sneak in a backdoor clause to stop motorcycle ownership. Nor does a discussion of requiring more stringent state inspection standards for motorcycles introduce cries of tyranny and slippery slopes towards forced public transportation. And certainly no one says or even thinks that a hypothetical state law from forbidding people under the age of 18 riding motorcycles on highways is an assault on the commerce clause of the Constitution.

# News comment title:
Do Small Businesses Deserve Exemptions From the Minimum Wage?

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
If nothing else, Hibbs just got the word out for his new graphic-novel-of-the-month club. I just signed up.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Contrary to every right winger, not every job is a job worth having.  There should be a minimum expectation for each job of a decent wage with appropriate benefits.

If an employer can't meet those minimums, then it is apparent that their business is not financially viable.  Expecting the employees to make up the difference for an employer's lack of business ability is typical of many business owners and managers who believe that they are doing the US a favor by hiring people at poverty wages and dumping the costs on everyone else's tax money.
 
It shouldn't make a difference whether they are teens or second jobs.  What our "race to the bottom of the wage scale"  employers want is a nation of low paying second jobs.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Its no more an assumption that your belief that raising the minimum wage is going to be helpful for everyone.

Raising the minimum wage, in general, is a great idea.  But every great idea is not going to work in every case.  A means-tested hardship clause of some kind is not going to break society.

The real target of minimum wage laws are the large employers that are not paying their employees what the market can bear.  A business with a 5 to 10 percent profit margin isn't going to be able to afford to absorb double digit percentage increases in wages for its employees.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

What services are discounted by sharing the cost amongst all the states?  The military.  Disaster response.  Agricultural subsidies.  Corporate subsidies.  The post office.  Border patrol.  All of the diplomatic relations that are currently handled by the federal government.

Right now Texas is not responsible for any of those things, beyond their financial contribution.  As an independent nation, it would have to form government entities to handle all those things.  They're not free.  They have payrolls, buildings, fleets, material, and all the other costs associated with them.  

That money has to come from somewhere, and the only place a government gets its money is taxes.  So Texans would now pay every dollar they do to the federal government, plus more to cover all the overhead which is now necessary because its not being provided by the feds.

Imagine a homeowner who decides to secede from a town, and for sake of argument, that they let him.  He's making the same about of money, and no longer contributing to the city taxes.  

Of course, he also has to set up his own fire prevention and response, his own protection from crime, his own water supply, negotiate his own deals with the power company, etc.  All without the collective bargaining power of a larger city, so you can bet that he won't get the same rate as that town he just left.

# News comment title:
Texas Wants Its Own Fort Knox

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
One more way to saber-rattle about secession. These hacks are so obvious. It's a good thing they have a mutual idiot admiration society to shield them from the rest of the country's laughter, otherwise they'd have to shoot themselves with their Big Texas Guns out of sheer embarrassment. 

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


You probably also think balancing the budget is as simple as balancing your home checking account, don't you?

You're analogy is missing the point in so many ways. First, the numbers themselves:

If you have a house, valued at $1M, and it burns down, you will spend far more than $1M to replace it.  You have to start from scratch, and the total value of the materials and labor will exceed the estimated (and usually depreciated value) of the old house.  The cost is >$1M, not equivalent. 

Secondly, in Texas' case, we're not talking about one for one replacements. Texas secession is like moving from a rented house to a mortgaged one. In the first situation, costs are passed on with rent, and major building costs are shared amongst all tenants. 

When someone moves to a house, their costs go up. They're now solely responsible for all costs. Unless the house is significantly smaller than the old apartment, all costs will rise. 

Texas assuming responsibility for all the services a national government has to deliver, as opposed to a state, works the same way. 

>>> END COMMENT <<<

Two additional points in refutation of Capper's claims. One is that Capper's research is funded by the Beef Councils of Iowa, Kansas, Nebraska, South Dakota and Washington. 


Two is that Capper's claim that it would take an "additional 135 million acres" to support the growing of grass-fed meat is a slight of hand. Today there are 150 million acres devoted to growing corn and soy - the vast majority of which goes to animals raised in confined feedlot operations. Those 150 million acres of corn and soy were once grasslands, but are now corn and soy "factories" doused with fossil fuels, subsidized by tax-payers. We don't need a net new 135 million acres. We need only eliminate CAFOs, and at the same time, allow those 150 million acres of mono-cropped corn and soy fields to revert back to grasslands. Win - win.

Maybe start a white guy hiring freeze for a couple years?

Also this article uses African American and black interchangeably, but I think if were talking about diversity in tech you really need to elaborate because I know a lot more African Africans working in Tech than African Americans.  There are some of course, but CompSci doesn't really seem to be a common course of study for most of the African Americans I know.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
There are two sides to this issue. I am black. I have worked in and with the tech sector recruting since the mid 90's. I  have also worked with Jessie Jackson on this issue. California has been experiencing a huge out-migration of black people for more than two decades now. Many blacks have moved to more affordable places in the south such as Atalanta, Houston, and Dallas. Also, Black students who have been accepted to Universities like U.C. Berkeley, have turned those offers down because of reports that the campus is inhospitable to blacks. The issue is so much larger than just the fact that blacks are underrepresented in these companies. Blacks are underrepresented in California, period, primarily because they fear the high cost of living and are moving to places where they feel that their is more cultural support and community.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


The article is correct only in the most superficial, least examined way.  Yes, there's very few black people in these tech companies.   

But when you want to start accusing these companies of racism, direct or indirect, intentional or otherwise, you better come with a lot more proof than this.  The article is borderline slanderous, and comments like yours are past the line.  You have assumptions and preconceived notions, not data, and you're making the accusations.

These companies recruit everywhere, but recruiting is a far cry from mounting nationwide hunts to find people from a specific race for new positions (which, btw, is probably illegal).  Its also silly for them to do so when they have all manner of people trying to get the jobs without extra effort on their part.

There probably are many qualified black people throughout the nation for these jobs.  But "qualified" does not also mean "available, interested, willing to relocate, and work for this company."

If nepotism is the issue, and it is a big "frat boy party"-- which is so reductive its informative of the substance of your argument-- then the problem REMAINS education.  Why aren't black people in the education system where those connections are made?



By the way, I'm also sick of this "priviledge" argument.  People like yourself wield it (tellingly, as the last line), like its some final word that will make everyone suddenly realize that all the uninformed, unsupported claims you're making are miraculously true, just because they haven't lived exactly the same life as someone else.  Its nonsense.



You don't have to be black to understand societal problems any more than you have to be a plumber to understand that the leak in your shower needs to be fixed.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


The SC does not decide constitutional rights. It arbitrates whether laws are in line with constitutional rights. 

Only amendments can create, remove, or alter constitutional rights. If that was untrue, Roe v Wade couldn't be overturned. But it could be overturned tomorrow- it probably won't, but it could be. 

The SC could not overturn the first amendment tomorrow. At most, it can rule to the extent it can apply reasonably. 

It's a pedantic difference perhaps, but not unimportant. 

And the law makes no distinction for motive. It is equally unfair to tell someone their opinion is invalid because it's based on religion as it is to impose religion on a non-believer. 

Our laws are created by the consensus of the strongest will, whether that's through majority or through other means. The motivation for the laws is immaterial. 

Freedom of religion means only that the government cannot support one religion above others. It has nothing to do with how individuals make decisions about right and wrong.

# News comment title:
Apple Is Yet Again Making a Play for the Corporate Market

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
This goes back to the original conflict between Gates and Jobs. Both wanted a computer in every home, but Gates thought the best way was to out it on their desks at work first, while Jobs went straight for the private consumer. The 90's proved Gates correct, but Apple strormed back with the I Pad and I Phone, but Gates always felt that eg personal use angle would have diminishing returns and that business would have ever expanding needs for new tech. Apple has seen stiff competition and diminishing returns on the gadgets. Gates was more about software, but it was always about the application of technology, hard or soft, and there are orders of magnitude more uses for it in business. This is a case where Jobs ego and belief that he is always right eventually would have gummed up the Apple works had he still been around. They are a bit late to the game on this

I wonder if that lesson is sinking in yet. # Most liked comment (from the thread): Your search for beloved programs that don't have those three characteristics is just a little too cute. There is almost certainly a way to test a program that doesn't meet characteristic #2 right across the Atlantic: scores of European countries have universal health care; powerful unemployment coverage; public housing; childcare; and other similar programs. They exist at various levels of generosity and universality. The more universal (in use and in possibility of being used someday, rather than in a more Rawlsian sense), the more loved. And the reason there is no way to test a program that doesn't meet characteristic #3 is that it's circular with #1: all programs that are universal are seen as paid for. Universal benefits are part of the social contract. We assume that the taxes we're paying as part of that social contract are worthwhile because we're getting something back for them. When it comes time to look for something like that, my reaction is "Lo! here stands this universal program I have access to at zero marginal cost! It appears it is paid for!" To take the most prominent European example, Britons hate the idea of the NHS being gutted in large part because they've paid for it; if I've paid for my health care already, why on earth would I want to put that care at risk? It's MINE! What's more, their payment for it goes from pragmatic to a point of national pride. The NHS is a triumph of British society, and to the extent any part of the UK is looking to leave, they promise an even more generous guarantee of health care at the very least. So then you're left with #1: are non-universal programs in danger. And you "would argue" this is irrelevant, but you don't actually do so. These programs are constantly under real threat of being taken off the table. Welfare reform happened. Cuts to lunch programs happened. Cuts to public housing and food stamps happened. So our non-universal welfare state is growing, but it is doing so in an unreliable way. Beyond that, means tested programs are less economically efficient. The argument that universal programs are better isn't just about money going into them; it's about how efficiently and effectively that money is used and what its effect on the overall economy is. Peter Lindert's book Growing Public examines data since the 19th century to make exactly this point: the size of the welfare state has no relationship to economic growth, but the structure of it does. And universal programs paid with broad-based taxes lead to better outcomes for the poor while also creating less economic drag. As to your point about the GOP attacking seemingly untouchable programs: that's true. And they get absolutely creamed for it every single time. # News comment title:
John Oliver Explains Why It's So Crucial Apple Is Refusing the FBI's Encryption Demands

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
I think a lot of people are misunderstanding how computer encryption works. Apple doesn't actually develop encryption algorithms. They're made by computer scientists around the world collaborating on greater and greater entropy algorithms. If Apple simply takes the data that's in the phone and hands it go the FBI, all they're going to get is encrypted gibberish. It would take current supercomputers hundreds of years to decrypt it by brute force. For that reason, the FBI wants Apple to hack their own operating system to not use strong encryption. But the problem is that it goes for everyone. Computers are all clones of each other. They hack this one phone, they hack all existing phones. And I want you to note that only a few months ago, the director of the FBI's personal information was hacked by a bunch of middle school students just for fun. That's the guy you think is really going to keep this "secret" from getting out to hackers? Wouldn't Russian, Chinese and North Korean hackers just loooove to get their hands on this.

# News comment title:
GMOs Are Probably Safe. They Should Still Be Labeled.

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
A tangential way to deal with the problem is to push for widespread adoption of one of the most common and difficult to control weeds as a cash crop.

It's common name is pigweed, and you see it all over the farm belt, not just in fields, but any empty lot it's growing wild.

Pig Weed is just a species of Amaranth, one of the popular, alternative seed foods, and is part of the same family in which you'll find Quinoa. It's scientific name reflects this fact Amaranthus palmeri

It's high oil content means it would make an ideal replacement for corn currently grown for bio fuel. Amaranth can even be popped like popcorn!

And like all quinoa like crops, it's high in protein and very nutritious overall losing nothing to Soybean in total offerings. You can even make milk from it.

If Amaranth were adopted in the Soybean and Corn growing regions, there would NO LONGER be a need to make GMO modified crops, because pig weed IS THE #1 REASON why they are going to such efforts.

Pig Weed is impervious to glyphosate.

Pig Weed is also extremely drought tolerant and will thrive given just a fraction of the water corn and soybean need to grow. 

It also needs NO extra fertilizer, at least not on the scale soybean and corn do, because it can absorb nitrogen from the soil directly. In fact it is so good at this, fertilizing it could easily result in a crop too loaded with nitrates for human consumption.

So on top of eliminating the need for GMO Corn and Soybean, it would also dramatically reduce the amount of polluting fertilizer run off that is a rapidly growing problem today. 

Unfortunately the loathing farmers hold it in has seeped into the public's consciousness causing many to reject the mere thought of using pig weed as a crop even while they eagerly accept using Quinoa and Amaranth.

It doesn't help that Pig weed is the ugly sibling in the amaranth family. 

Even a very healthy plant truly looks like a nasty weed. 

It lacks the beautiful big leaves and bright red seed heads of the the very closely related Mexican species that was once the main food crop of the Aztecs.

Without that sort of panache, it has almost zero fad potential that could lead to widespread adoption among the first groups in society whose choices often are the entry point for new sources of food to a very tradition bound nation.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Sorry, this is the review that looked at 162 studies:
http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19640946

Your issue then is with the pesticides, not the GE. That's what leviathan is saying.  

Trying to tar all GMO products as "dangerous" which seems to be the intended effect of the labeling movement, is a lie.

# News comment title:
Democrats Have a Class Gap. Republicans Have a Generation Gap.

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Ideology, just not the way you are thinking of it, plus a fresh voice and a more youthful thinker (not physically, just mentally and intellectually).

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
I don't know how "young" I count at 30, but there's a clear split within my personal cohort between people who follow politics in some detail, who never paid Sanders any mind given that the outcome was essentially never in question, and those who engage during presidential cycles who were excited about Sanders and developed weird chips on their shoulders about the "attacks" and "unfair treatment" he received. 

One friend in the latter camp donated hundreds of dollars and brings up the most recent slights when we speak. I tried to explain from the outset that it was completely futile and not getting worked up about, but it never really got through. 

I think for Millennial types at least there was a strong desire for the highs of another Obama cycle, and people really wanted Sanders to fill that role, even though it was never in the cards.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Ask most Bernie supporters how much their taxes will go up if he got everything he wanted. They'll look at you like you're from the moon, because it's always called "free" health care and college. 

"Older voters" realize things have political and economic cost. 

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
Sanders Superdelegates Want to Wrap Up the Revolution Peacefuly

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
What comes across strongly in the article is the belief that it's up to Clinton to bring the party together by shifting further to the left to embrace Bernie's policies, but there are problems with that POV. For example:

(1) If you place an immediate ban on fracking, the coal mines will have to be reopened to make up for the lost energy. That's self defeating. What's needed is.....(naughty word warning)...."incrementalism". Phase out fracking as renewables come online. And make a huge investment in speeding up that process. That's not counter-revolutionary, that's just pragmatic. But the Berners don't want to hear that.

(2) Breaking up the big banks is a great slogan and a commendable task, but even Bernie doesn't know how to do it. And my question is how do you do it without sending a panic through the financial industry that would bleed into the stock market and wipe out small investors? You know how the fear and loathing meme would go.....Which industry would be next on the hit list? Insurance? HMOs? Energy? Gotta be very careful there. The Sandernistas don't want to hear that either. 

More importantly, there's a limit to how much the guy who came in second can demand. And that limit gets ramped down the longer Bernie stays on the attack against HRC and the DNC. The longer he stays at war, the less likely it is that he'll be able to convince his extremely pissed off supporters to vote for Hillary in November. And if he can't deliver the votes, why should the DNC accommodate his demands? In this sense, I think Bernie is hurting himself badly, and apparently there's nobody who he'll listen to about it. Maybe when he talks with Obama? 

There are only three goals that should be topic #1 with the dems right now: (1) Elect HRC; (2) Take control of the Senate; (3) Create a liberal-leanng SCOTUS. Without those three prerequisites, Bernie's revolution doesn't stand a chance. The Berners want to go charging across a bridge that hasn't been built yet. Worse still, they're burning bridges that their actual, authentic allies are still standing on. That's not a good strategy.

# News comment title:
Cinemark Is Asking Survivors of the Aurora Massacre to Pay $700,000 in Legal Fees

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Rather than suing the shooter, who has no money, or his family, for not acting when they knew he was mentally ill, the plaintiffs went after the deep pockets. They lost, as any competent attorney would have predicted. They lost, as any competent attorney would have predicted. Defending against this ridiculous lawsuit cost a lot of money, and under the law, Cinemark is entitled to ask for payment from the people who launched the action.

This is how it works. Trying to get a big payday out of a tragedy can backfire, and leave you holding a very impressive set of bills from the lawyers on both sides. The families need to show up for these hearings, and be honest about their financial situations. Pretty sure the judge will lower the amount.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


If they had, Cinemark would have been doing something that no other theater was doing (or does now, for that matter).  You can't hold a company accountable for not doing something that would be way beyond reasonable expectations and norms, simply because they failed to predict the actions of a madman.


And, none of that would matter anyways, because the shooter propped the exit door of the theater open, went to his car for his armor and weapons, and reentered through the theater.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
This is the DARKEST of the Monsanto protection acts.  It exempts the majority of GMO products has no penalty for those who fail to label, waits two years and then expects people to scan codes.  It blocks hundreds of local GE bans including those by Native Americans.

Maui produces the majority of the globe's transgenic and cisgenic traits.  We voted for a moratorium on open air creation of new organisms Until Independent Longterm Heath and Environmental Impact Studies.  Monsanto/Dow-DuPont spent the most per vote in the history of US elections and still lost.  Instead of just conducting the tests Monsanto/Dow-DuPont just sue and buy laws like this DARK act.  Hawaii and Vermont are small state's but we still deserve the protection of the tenth amendment.

# News comment title:
If You're Determined to Vote for a Third Party, Here’s How to Minimize the Damage

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
How anybody could vote for Gary Johnson is beyond me.  He makes Trump almost look intelligent.  Just last night, he couldn't name a single foreign leader.  He wants to get rid of social security, public assistance for college, and Medicare.  He wants to remove business government regulations and hasten the return of the robber barons.  He wants to screw the middle class with taxes, while further reducing those on the rich.  Libertarians will always just be conservative Republicans that think trickle down is a liberal economic policy.

Any progressive that thinks that just because Johnson wants to legalize pot is worth a vote, is less intelligent than a Trump supporter.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<

But you do have to accept that whatever choice you make (even choosing not to vote) does have an impact on the election, and you need to be prepared to accept that if you don't like the outcome of the election, you could have chosen differently.

Basically, if Trump wins, and you could have done your part to change that, are you going to be okay with it after the fact?  If so, then fine, peace be with you.

In general, I think the principles you're talking about are sound, but as with most things, there has to be some limits and protections built into the system as well.

How you can seriously argue for safe-spaces for controversial speakers, free from heckling or protest, while simultaneously lambasting college students for supposedly being coddled in safe spaces, protected from opposing views?
Because that's not my line of argument? If it was just a matter of disagreement, I wouldn't be arguing at all. I'm not saying that people should get whatever platform they want, whenever they want, free from all criticism. Protesting and criticizing people's ideas is not the problem. Protesting them being allowed to speak, which is what happens when people (be they students or otherwise) demand speakers be disciplined, fired or disinvited IS a problem. Shutting down engagements through threat of violence is just the most extreme example of the issue. The specific instances may not be an institution-wide problem, but the mindset that leads to those actions is.
